citations.narrative:
The licensee was not able to provide records with the disposition information for a fennec fox, two wildebeest, and four
young coatis that had been sold.
Failure to maintain disposition records for animals sold can make it difficult to track their movement and ensure accurate
inventory counts.
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully disclose the information concerning animals,
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or
which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that exhibitor.
Correct by: 5/31/23 .

There were various enclosures in need of repair.
In the wolf enclosure, the wooden platform in the rear left corner has started to collapse. Several of the boards have
fallen to the ground and appear unsteady.
In the tiger enclosure, on the right side of the walkway, three wooden boards have partially detached from the wire panel
on the top of the enclosure. In the other tiger enclosure, a wire panel has become detached from the wooden boards
where the animals walk from one section of the enclosure to the other. The detached wire panel has caused several wire
ends to become exposed which has created sharp points in the enclosure. There is also a partially detached wooden
board on the outside of the enclosure in the same area.
In the bear enclosure, the left corner of a wire panel has become detached from the wooden boards of the den area.
In the large livestock pasture, there is a section of wire fencing, used to separate pastures, that has become detached
from the posts. In the corner near the small addax pen, there are also several wire ends, approximately 2-3" long
projecting into the livestock enclosure creating sharp points.
Failure to maintain animal enclosures and fencing can result in sharp points and unsteady structures which can cause
injury to the animals.
Housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain them.
Correct by: 06/13/2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee was not able to provide records with the disposition information for a fennec fox, two wildebeest, and four 
young coatis that had been sold.   
Failure to maintain disposition records for animals sold can make it difficult to track their movement and ensure accurate 
inventory counts.  
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully disclose the information concerning animals, 
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or 
which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that exhibitor. 
Correct by: 5/31/23 . 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There were various enclosures in need of repair.  
In the wolf enclosure, the wooden platform in the rear left corner has started to collapse.  Several of the boards have 
fallen to the ground and appear unsteady.  
In the tiger enclosure, on the right side of the walkway, three wooden boards have partially detached from the wire panel

on the top of the enclosure.  In the other tiger enclosure, a wire panel has become detached from the wooden boards 
where the animals walk from one section of the enclosure to the other.  The detached wire panel has caused several wire 
ends to become exposed which has created sharp points in the enclosure.  There is also a partially detached wooden 
board on the outside of the enclosure in the same area.   
In the bear enclosure, the left corner of a wire panel has become detached from the wooden boards of the den area. 
In the large livestock pasture, there is a section of wire fencing, used to separate pastures,  that has become detached 
from the posts.  In the corner near the small addax pen, there are also several wire ends, approximately 2-3" long 
projecting into the livestock enclosure creating sharp points. 
Failure to maintain animal enclosures and fencing can result in sharp points and unsteady structures which can cause 
injury to the animals. 
Housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain them. 
Correct by: 06/13/2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
